_data.title: Introduction

_data.text:
<base-alert>
This book is in beta right now. Meaning, I'm still writing it. Please be patient with me.
</base-alert>

Welcome to **Python for Research**. This book is meant to be a comprehensive guide on how to use Python and its various libraries for research puposes. There will be discussion of Statistics, Data Collection, Data Analysis, Hypothesis Testing and how Python can be used for these puposes.

## The goal of this project

This is an ambitious project. The goal of this book is to act as a reference. Hence, I opted for putting this online for free compared to publishing it. Also, I'm not a professional writer and I won't pretend to be. The writing might not be stellar, but it will do its job. 

## To get the most out of this book

This book is written to be read in a non-linear fashion. Pick and choose what you want to read, and don't forget to go through the [case-studies]() and [code]() examples.

Programming principles and the Python language is not covered in this text. If you find yourself lacking in these departments, you can take an undergraduate-level introduction to programming course.

## What is covered?

There is some kind of logical order that I have to follow to make this book easier to navigate. I have chosen to group this information in an order that makes sense to me. However, don't attach much importance to this. Just read it as you'd like to and you should be fine. I have provided links to the appropriate place if a concept is explained better there.

### Module - Fundamentals

This module contains the basic information needed to make sense of the other modules.

**Chapter - Getting Started**, The front matter and an introduction to the book. Also, explains setting up your environment.

**Chapter - Python Libraries**, Basics of the various python libraries and modules needed. We'll discuss Pandas, Jupyter notebooks and the various features.

**Chapter - Statistics**, A quick overview of descriptive and inferential statistics.

### Module - Data Handling

This module contains how to handle and process data to make it workable.

**Chapter - Data Collection**, How to collect data from various sources and convert it in a format you can work with.

**Chapter - Data Processing**, How to process and store data and reduce it in a form that is suitable for Exploratory Data Analysis.

### Module - Hypothesis Testing

This module covers the steps required to explore and visualize data and deduce some initial conclusions.

**Chapter - Data Visualization**, Visualizing data using the matplotlib, seaborn Pandas plotting and bokeh Python libraries

### Module - Machine Learning

**Chapter - Linear Algebra**, A quick overview of linear algebra and its associated functions.

**Chapter - Regression**, Regression Analysis using Python. Explains linear and logistic regression using scikit-learn library.

**Chapter - Classification**, Classification techniques such as naive Bayes, decision tree, K-nearest neighbors, and SVM.

**Chapter - PCA and Clustering**, Explains Principal Component Analysis and Clustering algorithms.

**Chapter - Other Data Types**, How to work with textual and image data types.

## Get in touch

Your feedback is always welcome. Whether it is general feeback, errata, or anything else, you can email me at paravksingla@gmail.com. If you want an offline copy of this book, you can find the code here.

_data.text:
## Python

The installer file for Python 3 is available on the [official website](https://www.python.org). I am going to use [Python 3.9.6](https://www.python.org/downloads/release/python-396/) which is the latest version at the time of writing. So, the code examples should definitely work for any of the **Python 3.9.x** versions.

<base-alert type="info">
Python 3.9.x doesn't work on Windows 7 or earlier. You can use Python 3.7.x and most of the code examples should still work fine. If things break, however, google is your best friend.
</base-alert>

You can check the version of python installed like this:

<code-group>
  <code-block label="Windows" active>

```bash
# In a command prompt window
python --version
```

  </code-block>
  <code-block label="Mac">

```bash
# In a terminal window
python3 --version
```

  </code-block>
</code-group>

I'll not provide any instructions for linux users because you should already know what you're doing.

## Libraries

To install a library, you can use **pip**

```bash
# In a command prompt or terminal window
pip install numpy
```
This should install numpy on your system. If you have multiple versions of Python installed, things might not work so smoothly. You should use google. You can also use other Python distributions like Anaconda. I'm not going to include instructions for those. You do you.

## Jupyter

We're going to use Jupyter Lab as our development envrionment. Some people prefer using only the classic jupyter notebooks and not the lab.
To install jupyter notebook:

```bash
# In a command prompt or terminal window
pip install jupyter-notebook
```

And to install jupyter lab:

```bash
# In a command prompt or terminal window
pip install jupyterlab
```

Once installed, launch Jupyter Lab:

```bash
# In a command prompt or terminal window
jupyter-lab
```

If you only want to use the classic jupyter notebooks and not the lab:

```bash
# In a command prompt or terminal window
jupyter notebook
```

<base-alert type="info">
If this stuff is confusing, just use jupyter lab. That's what I'm going to use.
</base-alert>

### Running Jupyter

The command `jupyter-lab` will start a server on your machine and open a browser window. This is our development environment.

//Todo: Add a picture

However, there is a problem with this setup. By default, the jupyter server will run from the path `C:\Windows\system32` on Windows. This means your files will be created here, which is not something you might like. Before running, you should point to your working folder.

```bash
cd D:\Workspace\P4R
jupyter-lab
```
